Award.AwardTitle: High-efficiency self-resonant transmitters and receivers for wireless power transfer

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wireless power transfer has emerging and potential applications such as charging personal electronics and electric vehicles, and powering wireless sensors. However, at present, the capabilities in terms of distance and efficiency are limited. This work will develop a new self-resonant structure to replace the transmit and receive coils now used, and enable improvements in distance and efficiency. The structure can be fabricated using low-cost non-toxic recyclable materials, and is scalable for a wide range of power levels, frequencies and sizes. The increased efficiency of this new approach can allow migration from conventional wired connections to wireless power transfer with minimal loss of efficiency, while expanded use of wireless power can facilitate beneficial new technologies such as low-cost sensor networks and electric vehicles. The quality factor Q of the resonant circuits used for transmitting and receiving wireless power is an essential figure of merit that determines the achievable distance and efficiency. The new resonant structures developed in this work are expected to achieve higher Q and therefore make longer distance and higher efficiency power transfer feasible. Beyond the application to wireless power transfer, the approach developed in this work may lead to more efficient resonant structures applicable to more conventional power and energy applications.

Two geometries of the resonant structure will be developed. A planar version uses a stack of thin foil conductors separated by thin polymer dielectric layers. Each foil is much thinner than a skin depth, thereby overcoming skin-effect losses. The capacitance between the foil layers resonates with the inductance of the current loop at the frequency of operation, such that the main high-current path is completely within the coil, eliminating the need for high-current connections exiting the coil, as well as eliminating the need for external resonant capacitors. The capacitors formed by the layers also act as ballast impedance in order to achieve equal current sharing between layers, a critical and difficult challenge in more conventional layered-foil windings. The planar technology works best in conjunction with a magnetic core that shapes the field to achieve the most effective coupling between the transmitter and receiver, and to minimize losses by making the field parallel to the foil layers. For higher frequency applications, where soft magnetic material performance is not as good, similar structures deposited in multiple steps on a toroidal substrate will be used to effect the same advantages without the need for a magnetic core.

Performance_Institution.Name: Dartmouth College - Thayer School of Engineering

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wireless power transfer is becoming important for applications ranging from electric vehicles to medical implants.  The capabilities of conventional wireless power transfer systems are constrained by capabilities of the inductive coils for transmitting and receiving energy.  This work developed a new high-performance self-resonant structure to replace the transmit and receive coils, and enable improvements in distance and efficiency.  The project included developing accurate models for the structures' operation and performance in a wireless power transfer system, designing structures for different applications, building the first high-performance prototypes, and demonstrating them experimentally.

The structure is based on a new concept for achieving very low loss in an electromagnetic resonator.  The structure uses a stack of thin foil conductors separated by thin dielectric layers.   Each foil is much thinner than a skin depth, thereby overcoming skin-effect losses.  The capacitance between the foil layers resonates with the inductance of the current loop at the frequency of operation, such that the main high-current path is completely within the coil, eliminating the need for high-current connections exiting the coil, as well as eliminating the need for external resonant capacitors.  The capacitors formed by the layers also act as ballast impedance in order to achieve equal current sharing between layers, a critical and difficult challenge in more conventional layered-foil windings. 

The performance of such a resonator can be quantified by the quality factor Q which is inversely proportional to power losses.  Quality factor in wireless power transfer systems is a critical factor constraining the achievable distance and efficiency.  The first new resonant structure developed in this work achieved a quality factor of Q = 1180, six times higher than a conventional coil the same size (6.6 cm diameter).  Based on this quality factor, we predicted greatly improved efficiency, and confirmed this with experimental measurements, including 98.8% efficient power transfer over a 22 mm distance and more than 80% efficiency over a 75 mm distance, where a conventional coil the same size would be expected to have less than 35% efficiency.

For some applications, the thickness of the structure needs to be minimized.  Techniques were developed to allow making a thinner version of the structure, just 3.5 mm high, while retaining a quality factor Q = 560, three times higher than a conventional coil the same size.  Beyond the application to wireless power transfer, the approach developed in this work was shown to be applicable to making efficient resonant structures for more conventional power and energy applications.  Based on the unprecedented performance achieved, it may lead to advances in other areas as well.

The work led to ten peer-reviewed publications, including eight juried conference papers and two journal papers, and led to formation of a startup-company, Resonant Link LLC, which has now received an NSF STTR grant to commercialize the technology.  Likely applications include:

  • Transportation electrification: Higher power and higher efficiency make the convenience of wireless power transfer possible without compromises.
  • Robotics and autonomous vehicles. Wireless charging makes operation without human intervention more practical.
  • Medical implants. Medical implants' capabilities are often severely limited by the power and energy constraints of batteries and current wireless power technology. Better wireless power transfer will allow new types of implants as well as improving the capabilities within existing categories.

Last Modified: 04/23/2019
Modified by: Charles R Sullivan

Images (1 of )
  • Layers of conductors and dielectric are stacked in a ferrite core to make a multi-layer self-resonant structure. The C-shaped conductors are stacked in alternate directions such that neighboring layers coupled by capacitance while all are inductively coupled by magnetic flux in the core.
    Aaron Stein
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Charles R Sullivan
    Concept of multi-layer self resonant structure
  • This prototype resonant wireless power transfer structure, 6.6 cm in diameter, has losses less than 1/6th those of a conventional coil. A pair of these is used to transfer power.
    Aaron Stein
    Charles R Sullivan
    Prototype resonant wireless power transfer structure
  • This prototype is only 3.5 mm high, but has less than 1/3 the power loss of conventional coils when used for wireless power transfer.
    Aaron Stein
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Charles R Sullivan
    Thin prototype resonant structure
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Wireless power transfer is becoming important for applications ranging from electric vehicles to medical implants. The capabilities of conventional wireless power transfer systems are constrained by capabilities of the inductive coils for transmitting and receiving energy. This work developed a new high-performance self-resonant structure to replace the transmit and receive coils, and enable improvements in distance and efficiency. The project included developing accurate models for the structures' operation and performance in a wireless power transfer system, designing structures for different applications, building the first high-performance prototypes, and demonstrating them experimentally. The structure is based on a new concept for achieving very low loss in an electromagnetic resonator. The structure uses a stack of thin foil conductors separated by thin dielectric layers. Each foil is much thinner than a skin depth, thereby overcoming skin-effect losses. The capacitance between the foil layers resonates with the inductance of the current loop at the frequency of operation, such that the main high-current path is completely within the coil, eliminating the need for high-current connections exiting the coil, as well as eliminating the need for external resonant capacitors. The capacitors formed by the layers also act as ballast impedance in order to achieve equal current sharing between layers, a critical and difficult challenge in more conventional layered-foil windings. The performance of such a resonator can be quantified by the quality factor Q which is inversely proportional to power losses. Quality factor in wireless power transfer systems is a critical factor constraining the achievable distance and efficiency. The first new resonant structure developed in this work achieved a quality factor of Q = 1180, six times higher than a conventional coil the same size (6.6 cm diameter). Based on this quality factor, we predicted greatly improved efficiency, and confirmed this with experimental measurements, including 98.8% efficient power transfer over a 22 mm distance and more than 80% efficiency over a 75 mm distance, where a conventional coil the same size would be expected to have less than 35% efficiency. For some applications, the thickness of the structure needs to be minimized. Techniques were developed to allow making a thinner version of the structure, just 3.5 mm high, while retaining a quality factor Q = 560, three times higher than a conventional coil the same size. Beyond the application to wireless power transfer, the approach developed in this work was shown to be applicable to making efficient resonant structures for more conventional power and energy applications. Based on the unprecedented performance achieved, it may lead to advances in other areas as well. The work led to ten peer-reviewed publications, including eight juried conference papers and two journal papers, and led to formation of a startup-company, Resonant Link LLC, which has now received an NSF STTR grant to commercialize the technology. Likely applications include: Transportation electrification: Higher power and higher efficiency make the convenience of wireless power transfer possible without compromises. Robotics and autonomous vehicles. Wireless charging makes operation without human intervention more practical. Medical implants. Medical implants' capabilities are often severely limited by the power and energy constraints of batteries and current wireless power technology. Better wireless power transfer will allow new types of implants as well as improving the capabilities within existing categories. Last Modified: 04/23/2019 Submitted by: Charles R Sullivan
